confusion_pairs.title: Allowlisting vs Blocklisting

a.definition: Only approved apps/processes are allowed to run (default deny).

b.definition: Known bad apps/processes are blocked (default allow).

bullets: Allowlisting is stronger but needs ongoing maintenance and exception handling.
Blocklisting is easier but fails against new/unknown malware.
Exam cue: high-security endpoints often prefer allowlisting.

confusion_pairs.title: Signature vs Heuristic/Behavior Detection

a.definition: Matches known patterns/hashes/strings of known malware.

b.definition: Flags suspicious behavior or characteristics, including unknown variants.

bullets: Signature is accurate for known threats; heuristics catch novel variants but can false-positive.
Heuristics often pair with sandboxing to observe behavior safely.
Exam cue: polymorphic malware tends to evade pure signatures.

confusion_pairs.title: Antimalware vs EDR vs XDR

a.definition: Primarily detects/prevents malware on endpoints (signatures + heuristics).

b.definition: EDR: endpoint detection & response; XDR: correlates across endpoint + network + cloud + email.

bullets: AV focuses on prevention; EDR adds deep telemetry, hunting, and response actions.
XDR correlates signals across multiple domains to reduce blind spots.
Exam cue: when asked about cross-platform correlation, pick XDR.

confusion_pairs.title: HIDS vs HIPS

a.definition: Host-based intrusion detection system: detects and alerts.

b.definition: Host-based intrusion prevention system: blocks/mitigates in real time.

bullets: Detection alerts; prevention enforces blocks (may impact operations).
HIPS is closer to 'active defense' on the host.
Both need tuning to reduce false positives.

confusion_pairs.title: Secure Boot vs Measured Boot vs Trusted Boot

a.definition: Prevents untrusted bootloaders/drivers by verifying signatures before execution.

b.definition: Measured boot records measurements to TPM; trusted boot validates each stage and can report health.

bullets: Secure boot blocks bad components; measured boot logs what actually loaded.
Measured boot enables remote attestation (prove boot integrity later).
Trusted boot focuses on chain validation and integrity assurance through boot stages.

confusion_pairs.title: TPM vs HSM vs KMS

a.definition: Hardware chip for platform integrity and key storage tied to a device (boot measurements, sealing).

b.definition: HSM: tamper-resistant key operations hardware; KMS: managed service to create/rotate/use keys.

bullets: TPM is per-device and great for boot integrity + disk key protection.
HSM is for high-assurance centralized key operations (e.g., CA keys).
KMS is often cloud-managed; still requires IAM and policy controls.

confusion_pairs.title: Clear vs Purge vs Destroy (Media Sanitization)

a.definition: Logical techniques that prevent simple recovery (overwrite, reset).

b.definition: Purge: more robust (degauss/crypto erase); Destroy: physically render unusable (shred/incinerate).

bullets: Clear is for reuse in same security domain; purge/destroy for higher sensitivity.
Crypto erase can be a purge method when keys are truly destroyed.
Destroy is final and often requires a certificate of destruction.

confusion_pairs.title: Crypto Erase vs Secure Erase/Overwrite

a.definition: Make data unreadable by destroying encryption keys.

b.definition: Actively overwrite or use firmware secure erase to remove data.

bullets: Crypto erase is fast for encrypted media, but only works if encryption was properly used.
Overwrite may be less reliable on SSDs due to wear leveling.
Exam cue: for SSDs, prefer crypto erase or vendor secure erase when available.

confusion_pairs.title: Secure Baseline vs Hardening vs Patching

a.definition: Known-good configuration standard to compare against (gold image).

b.definition: Hardening reduces attack surface; patching fixes known vulnerabilities.

bullets: Baseline is the target state; hardening is what you do to reach/keep it.
Patching is time-based and vulnerability-driven; baseline is configuration-driven.
Config enforcement keeps systems from drifting away from baseline.

confusion_pairs.title: Misconfiguration vs Insecure Defaults

a.definition: Vendor ships unsafe settings (e.g., default passwords).

b.definition: You set or leave settings incorrectly, exposing systems.

bullets: Insecure defaults are the starting risk; misconfiguration is the operational risk.
Configuration enforcement + baselines reduce both over time.
Exam cue: 'left open' or 'forgot to disable' points to misconfiguration.

antimalware.rule: Antimalware aims to prevent/detect malware on endpoints (signatures + heuristics).
antimalware.micro_example: A workstation blocks a known trojan hash during download.

signature_detection.rule: Signature detection matches known malware patterns; great for known threats, weak for novel variants.
signature_detection.micro_example: AV flags a file because its hash matches a known ransomware sample.

heuristic_detection.rule: Heuristic/behavior detection flags suspicious traits/behavior, helping catch new variants.
heuristic_detection.micro_example: A process injects into another process and starts encrypting many files—flagged as suspicious.

anomaly_detection.rule: Anomaly detection looks for deviations from normal behavior; needs baselines and tuning.
anomaly_detection.micro_example: A server starts sending large outbound data at 3 a.m., triggering an alert.

sandboxing.rule: Sandboxing runs code in an isolated environment to observe behavior safely.
sandboxing.micro_example: Email attachment runs in a sandbox; it tries to contact a C2 domain and gets blocked.

edr.rule: EDR provides endpoint telemetry, hunting, and response actions (isolate host, kill process, rollback).
edr.micro_example: SOC isolates a laptop after EDR detects credential dumping.

xdr.rule: XDR correlates detections across endpoint/network/cloud/email to improve visibility and response.
xdr.micro_example: XDR ties a phish email to a token abuse event and endpoint malware execution.

ioc.rule: Indicators of compromise (IoCs) are artifacts like hashes, IPs, domains, and registry keys used for detection.
ioc.micro_example: A known malicious domain is added to detection rules across tools.

hids.rule: HIDS detects suspicious activity on a host and alerts, but doesn't necessarily block.
hids.micro_example: A HIDS detects unexpected changes to system files and alerts the admin.

hips.rule: HIPS actively blocks malicious behavior on the host, preventing exploitation.
hips.micro_example: HIPS blocks a process from modifying protected registry keys.

host_firewall.rule: Host firewalls restrict inbound/outbound traffic at the endpoint level to reduce exposure.
host_firewall.micro_example: Block inbound SMB from public networks on laptops.

network_defense.rule: Network defenses complement endpoint tools: segmentation, monitoring, and policy reduce blast radius.
network_defense.micro_example: Endpoint is compromised, but network segmentation prevents lateral movement.

allow_list.rule: Allowlisting permits only approved software to run (default deny).
allow_list.micro_example: Only signed corporate apps can execute on kiosks.

block_list.rule: Blocklisting blocks known-bad software (default allow). Easier but less robust against unknown threats.
block_list.micro_example: Known PUP executable hashes are blocked by policy.

packing_obfuscation.rule: Packing/obfuscation hides malware to evade signatures; behavior detection and sandboxing help.
packing_obfuscation.micro_example: A packed executable looks different each time, so hash-based signatures fail.

polymorphism.rule: Polymorphic malware changes its code/signature while keeping behavior, evading basic signatures.
polymorphism.micro_example: A worm re-encrypts its payload each infection to change its hash.

configuration.rule: Configuration is the system settings state. Secure configurations reduce attack surface.
configuration.micro_example: Disable unused services and enforce strong TLS settings.

secure_baseline.rule: Secure baseline is a standard 'known-good' configuration used for comparison and drift detection.
secure_baseline.micro_example: Golden image for workstations includes firewall on, no local admin by default.

hardening.rule: Hardening removes/locks down unnecessary features, accounts, ports, and services.
hardening.micro_example: Uninstall unused software, disable legacy protocols, close unused ports.

misconfiguration.rule: Misconfiguration is a wrong setting you applied or left open; it’s a top cause of incidents.
misconfiguration.micro_example: An admin leaves RDP open to the internet without MFA.

insecure_defaults.rule: Insecure defaults are vendor-shipped unsafe settings; change them immediately.
insecure_defaults.micro_example: Default password on an IoT camera remains unchanged.

configuration_enforcement.rule: Configuration enforcement tools keep devices compliant with the baseline and prevent drift.
configuration_enforcement.micro_example: If a user disables firewall, the tool re-enables it and logs the event.

cis_benchmarks.rule: CIS Benchmarks provide prescriptive hardening guidance (baseline templates) for systems.
cis_benchmarks.micro_example: Apply CIS Windows benchmark settings via GPO and validate compliance.

security_compliance_toolkit.rule: Security compliance toolkits automate checking against baselines/policies and generate reports.
security_compliance_toolkit.micro_example: Scan endpoints weekly and report which controls are failing.

compensating_controls.rule: Compensating controls reduce risk when a primary control isn’t possible (temporary or constrained).
compensating_controls.micro_example: Legacy system can't be patched; isolate it in a VLAN and restrict access tightly.

patch_management.rule: Patch management is the process: evaluate, test, deploy, verify, and document patches.
patch_management.micro_example: Monthly patch cycle tests updates in staging, then deploys to production with rollback plan.

patching.rule: Patching applies fixes to remove known vulnerabilities. Verification matters.
patching.micro_example: After patching, verify the vulnerable CVE no longer triggers a scan finding.

hardware_vulnerabilities.rule: Hardware vulnerabilities (e.g., CPU flaws) may need microcode/firmware updates and mitigations.
hardware_vulnerabilities.micro_example: Apply BIOS/microcode update to mitigate a processor side-channel issue.

os_vulnerabilities.rule: OS vulnerabilities require timely patching and mitigation (config changes, disabling features).
os_vulnerabilities.micro_example: Disable legacy SMBv1 and patch the OS to fix remote code execution bugs.

firmware.rule: Firmware is low-level code on hardware; it can be a major attack surface and must be patched.
firmware.micro_example: Update UEFI firmware to fix a secure boot bypass.

uefi.rule: UEFI is modern firmware interface; supports features like Secure Boot.
uefi.micro_example: Secure Boot verifies signed bootloaders via UEFI policy.

hardware_root_of_trust.rule: Hardware root of trust is the physical trust anchor (TPM/secure enclave/PUF) used to verify integrity.
hardware_root_of_trust.micro_example: TPM stores boot measurements and protects disk keys.

secure_boot.rule: Secure Boot verifies signed boot components before running to block bootkits.
secure_boot.micro_example: A modified bootloader fails signature check and won’t load.

measured_boot.rule: Measured boot records what loaded (hash measurements) to TPM for later proof (attestation).
measured_boot.micro_example: System measures boot stages and can prove integrity to a management server.

trusted_boot.rule: Trusted boot validates each stage of the boot chain and can enforce integrity expectations.
trusted_boot.micro_example: Each boot component validates the next component before handing off control.

tpm.rule: TPM is a device hardware chip for secure key storage, sealing, and boot measurements/attestation.
tpm.micro_example: BitLocker disk key is sealed to TPM so disk unlock depends on expected boot state.

remote_attestation.rule: Remote attestation proves a device boot/config state to a remote verifier (often using TPM measurements).
remote_attestation.micro_example: A server proves it booted a trusted image before joining a cluster.

sealing.rule: Sealing ties a secret to specific platform state (TPM PCR values). If boot state changes, secret stays locked.
sealing.micro_example: Disk key is released only if boot measurements match expected values.

binding.rule: Binding ties a key to a device/TPM so it can’t be used elsewhere.
binding.micro_example: A key generated inside TPM can’t be exported and used on another host.

secure_enclave.rule: Secure enclaves isolate sensitive computations/keys from the main OS, reducing exposure to malware.
secure_enclave.micro_example: A private key operation happens inside an enclave even if the OS is compromised.

secure_erase.rule: Secure erase uses hardware/firmware features or controlled overwrite to remove data safely.
secure_erase.micro_example: Vendor secure erase command resets a drive to a clean state.

puf.rule: PUF (physically unclonable function) derives unique secrets from hardware characteristics (anti-cloning).
puf.micro_example: IoT device uses PUF-derived key instead of storing a static secret in flash.

hsm.rule: HSM is tamper-resistant hardware for key storage and cryptographic operations (high assurance).
hsm.micro_example: A CA private key is stored and used inside an HSM to sign certificates.

kms.rule: KMS is a managed key service for creating/rotating/using keys with IAM policies and audit logs.
kms.micro_example: Cloud apps use KMS to encrypt storage with customer-managed keys.

key_management.rule: Key management covers generation, storage, rotation, access control, backup, and revocation.
key_management.micro_example: Rotate service keys quarterly and restrict who can decrypt production data.

full_disk_encryption.rule: Full disk encryption protects data at rest; pairing with TPM improves usability and security.
full_disk_encryption.micro_example: Laptop disk is encrypted; it unlocks only after TPM confirms trusted boot state.

dlp.rule: DLP prevents sensitive data exfiltration using content inspection and policy enforcement.
dlp.micro_example: Block sending credit card numbers via email attachment.

asset_inventory.rule: Asset inventory is knowing what you have: hardware, software, versions, owners. You can’t secure what you don’t know.
asset_inventory.micro_example: Inventory reveals an unpatched legacy server still running on the network.

decommissioning.rule: Decommissioning is safely retiring systems: revoke access, archive data, sanitize media, update inventory.
decommissioning.micro_example: Before disposal, disable accounts, back up required data, then sanitize drives.

sanitization.rule: Sanitization is making data unrecoverable before reuse/disposal (clear/purge/destroy).
sanitization.micro_example: For sensitive data, purge with crypto erase or destroy media.

crypto_erase.rule: Crypto erase destroys encryption keys so encrypted data becomes unreadable quickly.
crypto_erase.micro_example: Delete the disk encryption key in KMS to render snapshots unreadable.

data_remanence.rule: Data remanence is leftover data that remains after deletion; requires sanitization to prevent recovery.
data_remanence.micro_example: Deleted files still exist in unallocated space until overwritten or sanitized.

degaussing.rule: Degaussing uses a strong magnetic field to erase magnetic media (not SSDs).
degaussing.micro_example: Degauss an old tape drive cartridge before disposal.

physical_destruction.rule: Physical destruction renders media unusable (shredding, pulverizing, incineration).
physical_destruction.micro_example: Shred hard drives containing highly sensitive data.

certificate_of_destruction.rule: A certificate of destruction documents secure disposal for audit/compliance.
certificate_of_destruction.micro_example: Vendor provides certificate after shredding encrypted backup tapes.

eol.rule: End-of-life means vendor no longer provides security patches; risk increases sharply.
eol.micro_example: An EOL OS must be replaced or isolated with compensating controls.

legacy_hardware.rule: Legacy hardware may lack security features and patch support; it often needs isolation and tight controls.
legacy_hardware.micro_example: An old PLC can't be patched; put it behind a firewall and restrict access.

embedded_systems.rule: Embedded systems have constrained resources; security relies on strong defaults, secure updates, and isolation.
embedded_systems.micro_example: A smart sensor uses signed firmware updates and minimal open ports.

rtos.rule: RTOS prioritizes real-time responses; patching and monitoring must be planned carefully.
rtos.micro_example: Apply updates during maintenance windows to avoid disrupting timing constraints.

iot_security.rule: IoT security focuses on secure defaults, firmware updates, segmentation, and identity/keys.
iot_security.micro_example: Change default passwords and isolate IoT devices on a separate VLAN.

ics_scada.rule: ICS/SCADA systems control industrial processes; availability and safety are critical. Use segmentation and strict access.
ics_scada.micro_example: SCADA network is isolated; remote access requires VPN + MFA + jump host.

plc.rule: PLCs are industrial controllers; they often run legacy protocols and need strong network isolation.
plc.micro_example: PLC programming port is restricted to an engineering workstation subnet.

rtu.rule: RTUs are remote telemetry devices; secure comms and authentication are key.
rtu.micro_example: RTU sends sensor data over encrypted channel with device certs.

wear_leveling.rule: Wear leveling in SSD/flash can make overwriting unreliable; sanitize with crypto erase or vendor secure erase.
wear_leveling.micro_example: SSD overwrite may miss remapped blocks; crypto erase is safer.

mac.rule: MAC (Mandatory Access Control) enforces policy centrally; users can’t override permissions.
mac.micro_example: Even root is constrained by MAC policy in hardened environments.

selinux.rule: SELinux is a MAC system for Linux that enforces policy rules on processes/resources.
selinux.micro_example: A web server process is denied access to user home directories by SELinux policy.

enumeration.rule: Enumeration collects detailed system info (users, shares, services) and increases attacker knowledge—monitor and limit it.
enumeration.micro_example: Exposed SMB shares reveal user lists and file structures to attackers.

attack_footprint.rule: Attack footprint is the exposed surface area of a system (services, ports, configs). Reduce it to lower risk.
attack_footprint.micro_example: Disable unused ports and remove legacy services to shrink footprint.

group_policy.rule: Group Policy (GPO) centrally enforces Windows configuration and security settings across domain-joined systems.
group_policy.micro_example: Enforce screen lock timeout and disable SMBv1 via GPO for all workstations.
